author: Ghost in a Jar

text: Its amazing to me how differently people can see things. You worry more about gameplay than an amazing story, but for me, why else would you play an RPG except for an amazing story? I would worry more about gameplay when it comes to Action/Adventure games.
author: DAWells1983

text: @DAWells1983 To me, any game's main focus should be gameplay. that's why it's a game. I appreciate it when the story is good, don't get me wrong, but if I am only looking for an amazing story then I have thousands of movies, TV shows and books that focus almost solely on the story.
author: ZakkVanBurace

text: Well, we'lI have to¬†agree to¬†disagree. To me, the story should always be the main focus. At least when it comes to RPG's. Im not looking for an amazing story in a fighting game. Game play should definitely be the focus there. For me, playing a really good RPG is no different that reading a good book. The only difference is that you play a part in the story because you guide your characters through the plot. Do you see what I mean? I mean, look at a game like Dragon Warrior 7. Game play is terrible, but quite possibly one of the best stories in any RPG that I've ever played. I take it by your Van Burace name that you are a fan of the first Wild Arms? Well, the game play in that wasn't anything special. Not by a long shot. But that story was epic.
author: DAWells1983

text: @DAWells1983¬†Hm I think I get your way of thinking. I understand it, although I think I could never finish a game whose gameplay doesn't appeal to me. I got you when you said that it's like reading a book. As for the Wild Arms thing, I'm a huge fan of the series precisely because its gameplay is, at least for me, way more fun than your average RPG; you know, with all those little puzzles, character tools and everything XD and of course the music as well.¬†
author: ZakkVanBurace

text: +DAWells1983 I agree with that, but I have to add one more criteria on top. For me, the way the story is told is what is most important. While gameplay comes into play it is not the most important, you are correct there. But without a good score the story will fall flat for me. I need the right emotions to emphasize certain parts of a story. This is basically what made me latch on to Wild Arms as much as I did when I was a kid. The story was awesome, the game looked awesome, gameplay was, well, it was an RPG. But the music was phenomenal! It drew me in and never let go. Still hasn't.
author: Jared Silvestri

text: +DAWells1983 I so agree with you. Not many people think like us.
author: rustypwns

text: I tend to focus on both. Then again, I can't think of any RPG with an excellent story that doesn't also have great gameplay. Well, I suppose Xenogears and Xenosaga were a bit simplistic, but I enjoyed them anyways.
author: Harkz0r

text: A game having an amazing story doesn't mean much if it doesn't play well, as you have to be able to want to be compelled to keep playing and a frustrating gameplay system can deter that.  Stories are a top in thing in RPGs no doubt, but to act like the gameplay isn't important is naive.
author: Joshua Carpenter

text: The Etrian Odyssey games are all about gameplay, and they''re a turn based rpg. I mean, there's a story mode for the remakes, but I don't really care for that personally.

author: Rusty8984

text: I haven't tried part 1 yet, but I have a copy of Alter Code F tucked away for a rainy day (or month). I don't really mind if the game is repetitive, as long as the puzzles get harder and the gameplay is pretty solid. I actually don't like it when an RPG tries to be some major set-piece production like Final Fantasy X. If I want an amazing story, I'll just read a book. WA3's dungeons and world reminded me of the great Zelda games for SNES/GBA. No killer story but great unbroken gameplay.
author: cleomagoolando

text: I think I mentioned it is one of the few games where I bothered with the sidequests. But compared to how refreshing part one was back in 96. You were learning moves in towns and dungeons with Jack. The girl's and guy's were interesting. There was a dungeon in the desert. Interesting plot points like the sky falling and a town with a demon barrier at its entrance. It felt repetitive, and the dungeons weren't visually distinctive. I did end up liking the game though.
author: GadGades

text: That's interesting. I think Symphonia is probably a harder game. But the puzzles were so weak they might as well not have existed. The only interesting one was when you had to write down some sentences that were in semi code.
author: GadGades

text:
thanks!
symphonia coul'd've been a bit harder indeed, though i thought most of the puzzles were a lot of fun! (i remember a dungeon where you had to collect and execute a rhyme about giants... really loved that bit!)

i'm going to check out w.a especially since the music is sooo good ^_^
author: garfreeek

text: WA3 was the first game in the series that I played and I found its style to be incredibly refreshing and solid. It takes a bit to grow on you, but the payoff is excellent. I also appreciated the sheer size of the quest, which in terms of most newer RPGs, is pretty remarkable.
author: cleomagoolando

text: I just started Wild ARMS 4, and while it plays great and the style is solid, I'm wondering why they had to get rid of the world map. Some people claimed it was tedious, but I loved searching the globe in Wild ARMS 3 and finding the dungeons, Millenium Puzzles, etc... not to mention how intimidatingly HUGE the world was. I guess the developers felt like they had to adhere more to Final Fantasy X's example, which is unfortunate.
author: cleomagoolando

text:
It doesn't matter. The stories are mostly unrelated, though the setting is the same world.

After putting out #3, they reissued #1 on the PS2 as 'Alter-Code F' and gave it virtually the same engine/gameplay-mechanics as #3.

It's interesting that you mention Tales of Symphonia and Wild ARMS 3 in the same post, as though are the last two games I played through. I really enjoyed Symphonia, but WA3 was a much more satisfying challenge. Symphonia's dungeon-crawling sections were way too easy.
author: cleomagoolando
